collection.collection_description:
WGLT, licensed to Illinois State University and affiliated with NPR, began as a student-operated closed circuit radio station on April 24, 1962. It received FCC licensing and began FM broadcasting in February 1966, becoming a full NPR member in the 1970s. 

The collection includes administrative files from the 1960s to the 2010s, containing the stationâ€™s constitution and policy statements, correspondence, committee materials, format and positioning statements, and surveys and petitions. Budgeting and reports from the late 1960s to the 1990s, as well as the 2010s also includes facilities information, and Congressional appeals. Program information and guides span from the 1960s to the 2010s. Audio and video materials from the 1970s to the 2010s include recordings played on the station, primarily on reel-to-reel tapes, though the titles on these reused reels and boxes are unreliable. Textiles from the 1990s and 2000s contain T-shirts, polo shirts, hats, and other promotional items. Ephemera and memorabilia from the 1960s to the 2010s include scrapbooks, photographs, plaques, and newsletters.

collection.historical_relevance:
Originally a student operated radio station, WGLT first signed on the air on April 24, 1962 as a closed circuit radio station. The station operated out of the Centennial building. A few years later, on February 4, 1966, the station received FCC licensing and began FM broadcasting. After moving to a studio in Cook Hall, the station broadcast with only 10 watts of power which was enough to reach student dormitories. By the 1970's, WGLT became a full member of the National Public Radio network and was later broadcasting at 25,000 watts. Offered as a public service of the university, the station currently offers talk and news programming as well as online streaming music channels that include blues, jazz, and acoustic music. The station's call sign is an acronym for "Gladly Learn Teach" which is a take on the university's motto: Gladly we learn and teach.

Note written by April Karlene Anderson (pulled from public finding aid)
